Harnessing big data
for agricultural excellence

Part 1: Understanding big data in agriculture

Marie-Hélène Burle

Simon Fraser University’s Big Data Hub &
BC Centre for Agritech Innovation

November 20, 2024


Who we are


Simon Fraser University

SFU hosts the Cedar supercomputer—a cluster of 100,400 CPUs and 1,352 GPUs soon to be replaced by an even larger computer cluster

Simon Fraser University

SFU also works with the Digital Research Alliance of Canada to offer researchers large amounts of computing power to solve challenging data and technology problems, as well as training to optimize their solutions


SFU’s Big Data Hub

Since 2016, Simon Fraser University’s Big Data Hub has been offering workshops, events, and consulting services to researchers and industry partners helping them remain at the top of the fast evolving data landscape


BC Centre for Agritech Innovation

Since 2022, SFU BCCAI has been helping small and medium enterprises in the farming industry to embrace technology driven solutions


BC Centre for Agritech Innovation



Goals for this workshop

Concepts

What is big data?

What is big data?

Big data can be defined by the 3 “V”:

  • Volume: Extremely large datasets with many observations and/or features

  • Variety: Very diverse data types (e.g. images, text, numerical) and structures

  • Velocity: Generated at high speed

Why now?

Recent years have seen an explosion of computing power

  • Large cloud servers
  • Faster internet connections
  • Better CPUs
  • GPUs, initially designed to accelerate computer graphics, proved well suited to run vast amounts of simple computations in parallel

GPUs’ new usage in particular opened the door to deep neural networks

More processing power

Why has big data become so essential?

Big data opens up the doors of machine learning—a subfield of artificial intelligence that can be defined as computer programs whose performance at a task improves with experience

With deep learning, it allows artificial neural networks to:

  • Calculate predictions
  • Generate novel data (generative AI)

The power of big data and AI

In typical computing, a programmer writes code that gives a computer detailed instructions of what to do

This works very well for a number of applications, but many tasks would require an impossible amount of code and resources

By feeding a very large amount of data to complex algorithms such as neural networks however, we can train them to become better and better at some tasks without explicitly programming how they should do so

The power of big data and AI

Example:

If you wanted to write a program that can recognize a dog in any image in a traditional computer programming fashion, you would have to write code analyzing images pixel by pixel and taking into account any possible dog breed, type of image (picture, blurred picture, drawing, cartoon, schematics…), dog positions, weather the dog is wearing clothes, etc.

This is an impossibly large task: there just isn’t enough computing resources in the universe to make this possible

The power of big data and AI

Example:

Yet, as humans, we can easily learn to detect a dog in an image

We intuitively create some abstract dog-model that we can then apply to any particular case we are presented with

The power of big data and AI

Example:

Big data and deep learning have recently made this possible for computers too: by feeding a very large number images with and without dogs with their accompanying label (“dog”/“no dog”) to a neural network however, we can now train that model to recognize dogs in images that it has never seen

This is a totally different approach from traditional programming: we are not explicitly programming the model on how to do this. We create a model and the model trains from the data

Big data in agriculture

Big data road map

Of course, the whole system works in an integrated fashion:

Wolfert, S., Ge, L., Verdouw, C., & Bogaardt, M. J. (2017). Big data in smart farming–a review. Agricultural systems, 153, 69-80.

Understanding neural networks

3Blue1Brown by Grant Sanderson has a series of 4 videos on neural networks which is easy to watch, fun, and does an excellent job at introducing the functioning of a simple neural network
